text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the Master of Prophets and Messengers, Muhammad, and upon his good and pure family.
To proceed, these are "News in Grammar" narrated by the master reciter (Al-Muqri), the trustworthy Abu Tahir Abdul Wahid bin Umar bin Abi Hashim Al-Baghdadi from his Sheikhs.
I have preceded it with an introduction about its narrator Abu Tahir, and mentioned his Sheikhs, students, and works. Then I mentioned the two manuscripts of the News and the chain of their narration, then I alluded to their content.
I commented on the News with brief comments, and provided biographies of the narrators of the News from Abu Tahir and those whom I knew from the men of the chains of narration and the News. I shortened the biographies and sufficed with mentioning some of their sources.
I placed following the text of the News the layers (Tabaq) of hearing it, then I mentioned the sources and references I referred to in investigating the News and commenting on it.
These News were published for the first time in Damascus University Journal in issue 15, year 1988. Only those who came across the journal issue saw it, and they are few.
This is a second edition, increased with revision, commentary, and correction, which I present to the readers of Arabic after exerting effort in investigating the News, commenting on them, and providing biographies of those I knew of their men.

text:
Abu Tahir bin Abi Hashim (1)
He is Abu Tahir Abdul Wahid (2) bin Umar bin Muhammad bin Abi Hashim Yasar Al-Baghdadi Al-Bazzar (3).
His birth was in Rajab in the year 280 AH, and he died on Thursday with ten [days] remaining of Shawwal in the year 349 AH (4). His son prayed over him in the Mosque of Rusafa, and he was buried in the Khayzuran cemetery.
He dedicated himself to memorizing the Holy Quran and seeking the sciences of Quran, Hadith, Arabic language, and literature. He read some of Sibawayh's book under Ibn Durustawayh. He used to follow the Kufan school in grammar and was proficient in it.
He devoted himself to the readings (Recitations), so he heard from the prominent reciters of his era, and memorized what he received and comprehended it, so he became a master Imam, and led the teaching of recitation after his Sheikh, Imam Abu Bakr bin Mujahid.

Al-Nadim (5) said of him: "He was brilliant in delivery and teaching recitation, and knew a good portion of grammar." Al-Khatib said: "He was one of the most knowledgeable people regarding the letters of the Quran and the aspects of recitations." Al-Dani described him saying: "There was no one after Ibn Mujahid like Abu Tahir in his knowledge and understanding, along with the truthfulness of his dialect and the straightness of his path." Al-Dhahabi described him saying: "The reciter, one of the notables, and one in whom skill in Quran performance culminated." Ibn al-Jazari described him as "The Great Master, the Scholar, the Trustworthy." His student Abdul Aziz Al-Farisi said: "When Ibn Mujahid died, they agreed to put forward our Sheikh Abu Tahir, so he led the teaching of recitation in his assembly, and the seniors sought him out and formed circles around him."
Abu Tahir used to teach recitation in the alley of Abdul Samad bin Ali bin Abdul Rahman bin Al-Abbas in Baghdad. He used to punish for linguistic errors (Lah'n) in reading. His student Al-Hussein bin Ali bin Muhammad Abu Al-Abbas Al-Halabi said: "He used to sit for teaching recitation with keys in front of him. He would perhaps strike the reciter's head if he made a linguistic error, so I feared that and did not read to him, but heard his books from him."
He knew his own worth, and knew what he possessed and took pride in it. He entered "one day into the assembly of Ibn Mujahid after they had finished an issue that occurred between them. He said to them: 'Bring it forth.' They said: 'The answer to it has been exhausted.' He said: 'Bring it forth, for when lions are present, foxes pass wind.'"

Manuscripts of the News, Chains of Narration, Title, and Content

1 - Manuscripts of the News
No one who wrote the biography of Abu Tahir mentioned this treatise. Al-Rudani mentioned it in his book "Silat al-Khalaf bi-Mawsul al-Salaf" (1). I came across it some time ago in a collection preserved in the Bodleian Library in Oxford under number (F 77). It constitutes folios 47-51 of it, written in clear Naskh script, and the texts of the News and some names are vocalized, and their vocalization is correct.
On the first page is written the following text:
"News in Grammar / Narration of Abu Tahir Abdul Wahid bin Umar bin / Abi Hashim from his Sheikhs"
Below this is the text:
"I read all these News to our Sheikh, the Imam, the Allama, Taj al-Din, Hujjat / al-Arab, Abu al-Yumn Zaid bin al-Hasan al-Kindi, may Allah preserve him. And the mentioned group heard / with the chain mentioned at its beginning. I also heard from him Al-Mujtana by Ibn Duraid / and that was in sessions, the last of which was the second of Rajab in the year five hundred and ninety-nine. Written by / Muhammad bin Ismail bin Abdul Jabbar bin Abi al-Hajjaj, may Allah benefit him.
This is correct, written by Abu al-Yumn al-Kindi in his handwriting."
At the end of it is the hearing of a group, including Ibn Abi al-Hajjaj the owner of the copy, from Abu al-Yumn al-Kindi, which I have established at the end of the text.
Then I came across a second copy of it in collection number 1148 in Dar al-Kutub al-Zahiriyyah in Damascus. It constitutes folios 71-75 of it. It is written in clear Naskh script, and most of its words are not vocalized. On the first page of it is written the text:

In the left margin of it is the text:
"A part containing the Virtue of Grammar and Encouragement to Learn It / Collection of Abu Tahir Abdul Wahid bin Abi Hashim / Al-Muqri, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him / Narration of Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Ahmad bin Umar bin Hafs / bin al-Hamami al-Muqri from him / Narration of Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Muhammad bin Ali bin al-Allaf from him / Narration of Abu Tahir Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Silafi and Abu Muhammad / Abdullah bin Mansur bin Hibatullah / bin al-Mawsili, both from him / Narration of Abu Amr Uthman bin Ali / al-Qurashi from al-Silafi by Ijazah / Narration of Abu al-Fida Ismail / bin Umar bin Abi al-Fadl bin Nasr / al-Hamawi by hearing from him / And narration of Abu Talib / Abdul Latif bin Muhammad / bin al-Qubayti from Ibn al-Allaf (2) / Narration of Abu Muhammad Al-Qasim bin Muzaffar / bin Mahmud bin Asakir by Ijazah from him".
At the end of it in folio 74/2 is a hearing layer of a group including the owner of the copy Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin al-Mujalli and the scribe of the hearing Abdul Rahman bin Marwan al-Tabib from Abu Tahir al-Silafi in the year 575 AH, and at the end of the hearing in al-Silafi's handwriting is the text "This is correct, written by Ahmad bin Muhammad al-Asbahani".
In folio 75/1 are two hearing layers: The first contains the hearing of a group from Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Ahmad al-Khabri in the year 588 AH, and below it in al-Khabri's handwriting is the text "Correct hearing according to what is written above my handwriting. Written by Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Ahmad al-Khabri al-Farsi known as al-Firuzabadi on the date mentioned above in Cairo al-Mu'izziyyah, may Allah Almighty protect it".
The second layer contains the mention of the hearing of a group including al-Silafi, Sibt al-Khayat, Ibn al-Mawsili...

I have established all this at the end of the text.
I compared my copy from the Bodleian copy - symbolizing it with the letter "B" - with this Zahiriyyah manuscript, symbolizing it with the letter "Z". I finished investigating the News, commenting on them, and providing biographies for those I knew of their men on 3 Rabi' al-Awwal 1407 AH / 5 November 1986 CE.
After finishing all that, I received from the dear brother, the virtuous investigator Dr. Hatim Salih al-Damin on 3/12/1986 a letter informing me that the News of Abu Tahir - I had told him its story - had been published in Egypt and he sent me a photocopy of it, may Allah thank him and reward him. The title of the printed version is "Akhbar al-Nahwiyyin, by Sheikh of Reciters Abu Tahir Abdul Wahid bin Umar bin Muhammad bin Abi Hashim al-Muqri", investigated and introduced by Professor Dr. Muhammad Ibrahim al-Banna from a unique copy preserved in Dar al-Kutub al-Misriyyah under number 2187 in the Hadith index, and published by Dar al-I'tisam in Cairo 1981 CE.
I looked at the work of the virtuous doctor and saw that he did not give it its due of effort and scrutiny. It appears he found the News easy and was in a hurry, so he hastened in copying and commenting on them. He referenced some of the News he came across with approximate referencing, and shortened the biographies of the men he knew severely. So he misspelled words, omitted some words, was not correct in commenting in places of his footnotes, and erred in the biography of some of the men he provided biographies for. He remained silent about the biography of many of them, a large crowd, and about referencing some News. He did not notice some of its problems. Elaborating on all that deserves an article devoted to it. I did not see fit to allude to any of that in my comments, as it would require changing the structure of the work and enlarging it uselessly. 3 - Title of the Treatise
It appears that the collector of the News, Abu Tahir bin Abi Hashim, did not name it. That is why the copies differed in naming it: It was named in the Bodleian copy "B" as "Akhbar fi al-Nahw" (News in Grammar). It was named in the Dar al-Kutub al-Zahiriyyah copy "Z" as "Al-Hath 'ala Ta'lim (2) al-Nahw" (Encouragement to Teach Grammar), and named in its margin (3): "Fadl al-Nahw wa al-Hath 'ala Ta'allumihi" (Virtue of Grammar and Encouragement to Learn It). It was named in the Dar al-Kutub al-Misriyyah copy (4) "Printed" as "Akhbar al-Nahwiyyin" (News of Grammarians).
The first name is the most accurate and correct of these names, and it encompasses the other names, and only News 6 falls outside it. As for the other names, some News fall under them while the rest fall outside.

4 - Its Content
These News narrated by Abu Tahir bin Abi Hashim from his Sheikhs - numbering twenty-five news items - included mention of the first to establish grammar and the early grammarians (News 4 and 5), encouragement to learn Arabic and care for it (News 10, 11, 13, 16, 17, 25), the care of Mawali (non-Arab clients) for teaching grammar (News 7), and a poem by Al-Kisa'i describing grammar and encouraging its learning (News 25). Also mention of linguistic errors (Lah'n) (News 3, 9, 15, 18), disliking it (News 12), punishing for it (News 14), avoiding it (News 21), seeking forgiveness for it (News 22), and mention of men who do not make linguistic errors (News 1, 2, 8), and men who make linguistic errors (News 19, 20, 23, 24).
As for News (6), it is not of the chapter of these news, but rather of the chapter of criticism of men. News (18) may also fall under this chapter.
Most of the News are famous, and I have mentioned some of their locations. I did not find News (9, 18, 19). I spared no effort in investigating the News, commenting on them, and providing biographies for those I knew of their men. I ask Allah to make us among the sincere benefactors, and our last prayer is that praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds.

Abdul Aziz said to him: Who circumcised you (Khatanaka)? He said to him: The circumciser (Khattan) who circumcises people!! Abdul Aziz said to his scribe: Woe to you, with what did he answer me?! He said (2): O Prince, you made a grammatical error (Lahanta), and he does not know grammatical error. You should have said to him: And who is your son-in-law (Khatanuka). Abdul Aziz said: I see myself speaking with a speech Arabs do not know! I will not witness (meet) people until I know grammatical error (3). He said: So he stayed in the house for a week not appearing, and with him was someone teaching him Arabic. He said: So he prayed Friday prayer with the people while being one of the most eloquent people. He said (4): He used to give for Arabic and deprive for grammatical error, until visitors from the people of Medina and the people of Mecca from Quraysh came to him. He started saying to a man among them: From whom are you? He says: From Banu so-and-so. He says to the scribe: Give him two hundred Dinars. Until a man from Banu Abd al-Dar bin Qusai came to him. He said: From whom are you? He said: From Banu (should be Bani) Abd al-Dar. He said: You find it in your prize (referring to the error). He said to the scribe: Give him one hundred Dinars.

bin al-Nadr recited to us for Ali bin Hamzah al-Kisa'i al-Asadi (1):
Grammar is but an analogy followed
And in every matter it is benefited from
So if the youth sees (learns) grammar
He passes in logic (speech) a passing and expands
So everyone who sits with him fears him
From a speaking sitter or a listener
And if the youth does not see grammar
He fears to speak out of cowardice so he stops
So you see him raising the accusative and what
Was of genitive and of accusative he raised (nominative) (2)
He reads the Quran not knowing what
The I'rab (parsing) conjugated in it and made (3)
And he who knows it reads it
So if he doubts in a letter he returns
Looking into it and into its parsing
So if he knows the grammatical error he splits (corrects) (4)
So they are equal in it according to you
Sunnah among us is not like innovations (5)
